text:
Hey There everyone! Today
I'm going to share with you five more travel survival tips for Surviving Seoul.
Is Korea safe?That happens to be a very popular question on my blog
Today I'm gonna answer it like that (snaps!) (laughing)
Of course it is! Korea is one the safest countries I've been to yet! I've had friends  report their wallets missing

or lost and some honorable Korean mailed it back to them and their
money was still there!

Now that doesnt mean that crime doesn't exist and can't exist for
tourists and foreigners.
Should the honor system happen to be faulty, then you have CCTV!!!
CCTV happens to be this huge surveillance system all throughout Korea. If there were ever a crime, you can easily check out the CCTV footage to see what happened.

They have surveillance
cameras everywhere.. Neighborhood, stores, schools, classrooms.. you get the drift.

I have fun with cultural differences
because of what they considered rude and disgusting in one country,
...happens to be ok in another. In Korea, it's considered rude to blow your nose in public.

However is not considered rude if
you want to hack somethin up in a public place.

Thus,in order to navigate eating Korean food in cafes and restaurants while her
nose is running, which will happen to be

very spicy . You will simply have to grab a
issue and dab. Dab it, each time you eat. Or you can do what some Koreans do... (suck)
(suck) (suck)... Yeah, they suck it back up.
Offering Gifts or Money. In Korea, little forms of etiquette happen to be very important. For example is to offer things with both hands.
Travel Survival Phrases. The top four phrases are... Anyeong haseyo.
Kamsahamnida.
Or you can say... Gomapsumnida.  Gomapsumnidas tend to feel a little more formal.
Hwajangshil Odieyo?  This happens to be a most important question.  "Where is the toilet?"
And.... Odieyo?
It's very helpful if you have a map topoint at.
A sneaky tip here is using an Asian accent, when you're pronouncing an English word, sometimes, can hit the spot.
Korea has certain English words,  but it's pronounced in a Korean way
Coffee.  Copee.  Bus.  Boseou. Costco... this is one Iknow well because I used it a lot. Cos-u-tu-co.
Okay.  Oh-kay!  And you get the drift.

There are cooler better words out there. But I can think about right now off the
top of my head.
Where to go potty?
The public restrooms in Korea and actually happen to be more abundant than trash cans. Go figure.

Your Go-To Pit Stops are gonna be
metro stations hiking spots, and parks and cafes.
Hope I got you excited to travel to Korea now.
And I also hope I packed you with some good travel survival tips. If you wanna know more about Korea, check out that "i" icon up there.
that links some of my popular blog posts about Korea.
You know the deal until then, travel safe, smart and fun and may the
GRRR be with you!
